meta.title: LLM & Agentic Coding Knowledge Graph
meta.description: Hand-authored graph summarizing key frameworks, notes, and resources under _explore/LLM-research for LLMs and agentic coding.

nodes.label: LLM Agentic Coding
nodes.summary: Overall space of LLM-based agentic coding, workflows, and practices.

nodes.label: Response Awareness
nodes.summary: Metacognitive methods where models label and respond to their own generation patterns.

nodes.label: System Prompts & Transparency
nodes.summary: System prompts, safety scaffolds, and transparency/observability around AI behavior.

nodes.label: Evolutionary Architecture
nodes.summary: Biologically inspired, signal-driven and evolutionary approaches to code and architecture.

nodes.label: Vendor Best Practices
nodes.summary: Best-practice guides and official documentation from model providers.

nodes.label: Agentic Frameworks
nodes.summary: Frameworks and toolkits for orchestrating multi-agent workflows and AI-assisted development.

nodes.label: Response Awareness Framework
nodes.summary: Meta-cognitive orchestration system that channels response generation awareness into structured multi-agent workflows.

nodes.label: Pantheon Framework
nodes.summary: Glass Box Process-based framework for custom AI teams and software development workflows with auditable artifacts.

nodes.label: BMad CORE + BMad Method
nodes.summary: Collaboration-optimized reflection engine with modular agents and workflows for human-AI co-development.

nodes.label: Agentic Context Engine (ACE)
nodes.summary: Playbook-based agent learning system that improves agents over time through generator, reflector, and curator roles.

nodes.label: Cybergenic Framework
nodes.summary: Biologically-inspired framework that grows applications via evolutionary, signal-driven code generation and self-maintenance.

nodes.label: CL4R1T4S
nodes.summary: Collection of extracted system prompts and guidelines for major AI systems to improve transparency and observability.

nodes.label: Anthropic Agentic Coding Resources
nodes.summary: Anthropic articles and cookbooks on agentic coding, tools, MCP, and best practices for Claude Code.

nodes.label: System Prompts Collection
nodes.summary: Local collection of system prompts and tool schemas for various tools and platforms.

nodes.label: 7 Steps: Stop Claude Code from Building the Wrong Thing
nodes.summary: Spec-Driven Development methodology for preventing Claude Code from rewriting architecture with vague prompts.
sources: _explore/LLM-research/“7 Steps” How to Stop Claude Code from Building the Wrong Thing (Part 1)_ The Foundation of….md
_explore/LLM-research/“7 Steps” How to Stop Claude Code from Building the Wrong Thing (Part 2)_ Execution, Results, and….md

nodes.label: Additional Response Awareness Tags
nodes.summary: Extension of the Response Awareness tag taxonomy with additional metacognitive markers like poisoned path and phantom pattern.

nodes.label: Claude AI Response Awareness Early Slash Command Breakdown
nodes.summary: Early breakdown of response-awareness slash commands and how they interact with Claude's generation process.
sources: _explore/LLM-research/Claude AI Response Awareness Early Slash Command Break Down v2.md

nodes.label: Claude Code Subagents: The Orchestrator’s Dilemma
nodes.summary: Analysis of orchestration vs implementation roles for main agents and subagents in complex Claude Code workflows.

nodes.label: Agent Engineering (ClaudeLog)
nodes.summary: Foundations of custom agent design in Claude Code, including initialization cost, tool selection, and performance tradeoffs.

nodes.label: Custom Agent Tactics (ClaudeLog)
nodes.summary: Advanced tactics for chaining, composing, and evolving custom agents across disciplines.

nodes.label: Correlating Response Awareness to Coding Outcomes
nodes.summary: Experimental exploration correlating Claude's self-reported generation states with bug rates and coding outcomes.
sources: _explore/LLM-research/Correlating AI Claude's response generation awareness to verifiable coding outcomes v2.md

nodes.label: Getting Good Results from Claude Code
nodes.summary: Practical guide to specs, CLAUDE.md, and validation practices for reliable Claude Code usage.

nodes.label: LLMs as Interpreters: Probabilistic Runtime for English Programs
nodes.summary: Interprets Response Awareness as a compiler/runtime for English programs executed via LLM attention and token probabilities.
sources: _explore/LLM-research/LLMs as Interpreters_ The Probabilistic Runtime for English Programs.md

nodes.label: Response Awareness and Meta Cognition in Claude
nodes.summary: Connects Response Awareness methodology to research on metacognitive spaces in LLMs and explicit vs implicit control.
sources: _explore/LLM-research/Response Awareness and Meta Cognition in Claude.md

nodes.label: Science of AI Internal State Awareness
nodes.summary: Clipping that ties interpretability research and internal state awareness to the Response Awareness methodology.
sources: _explore/LLM-research/The Science of AI Internal State Awareness_ Two Papers That Validate Response-Awareness Methodology.md

edges.summary: Agentic frameworks are primary tools for realizing LLM-based agentic coding.
Best-practice docs guide safe and effective agentic coding.
System prompts and transparency shape how agentic coding behaves in practice.
Spec-Driven Development is a core methodology for steering agentic coding.
Practical Claude Code usage patterns influence your broader agentic coding habits.
Response Awareness Framework is one of your primary multi-agent orchestration systems.
Pantheon Framework is a core reference implementation for AI teams and workflows.
BMad CORE provides modular agents and workflows that complement your other frameworks.
ACE adds execution feedback and playbook learning to agent workflows.
Cybergenic adds evolutionary, signal-driven development patterns to your toolkit.
ClaudeLog agent engineering concepts inform how you design and tune agents in these frameworks.
ClaudeLog tactics guide advanced combinations and chains across frameworks.
Framework operationalizes response-awareness concepts into concrete workflows and slash commands.
Additional tag set deepens the Response Awareness taxonomy.
Early slash command breakdown documents how Response Awareness was first prototyped.
Experimental write-up connects response-awareness practices to measurable coding outcomes.
LLMs-as-interpreters explains Response Awareness as a probabilistic runtime for English programs.
Meta-cognition article links Response Awareness to research on metacognitive spaces.
Internal state awareness clipping connects interpretability work to the framework.
Framework design is informed by Anthropic interpretability and agentic coding research.
Subagent architecture article explains orchestration choices inside the framework.
Spec-driven development patterns integrate with Response Awareness orchestration.
CL4R1T4S aggregates system prompts and guidelines from many providers.
Local system prompts directory stores your own prompt and tool configurations.
Runtime framing clarifies how system prompts act as programs for model behavior.
Cybergenic Framework is your main evolutionary architecture experiment.
Anthropic docs define many of your baseline patterns for safe agentic coding.
Community best practices complement official Anthropic guidance.
Both provide multi-agent, process-focused frameworks that can coexist and cross-pollinate.
Pantheon’s glass-box processes align with Response Awareness’ explicit tagging and verification.
ACE-style execution feedback can be layered into BMad workflows conceptually.
ACE-style learning could be applied to Cybergenic’s evolutionary runs in principle.
Tactics article assumes the foundations laid in the engineering article.
Both emphasize specs, context, and validation as keys to reliable Claude Code output.
V1 agent definitions form the historical baseline for orchestration design.
V1 skills represent the current stable skill set used in the system.
V1 commands capture the original command vocabulary for vibe code orchestration.
Exploratory agents provide patterns and ideas for future orchestration upgrades.
Exploratory MCP servers inform how external tools and APIs could be integrated.
Exploratory skills libraries offer candidate patterns for future specialized behaviors.
